I like the idea of having the parameters initially passed to the sequence being available to all actions.  If not and you need some parameters passed to an action later on in the sequence than the actions start to for dependencies on each other.  I would like to have the option of keeping them completely independent of eat other.

I made this mistake once - of assuming it was B. There is the risk that if you pass parameters to all actions, user might accidentally leak secrets to actions they did not intend to leak. If we support both, some questions then:
1. what's the common case default.
2. how do you merge parameters from the initial input with the result produced by an action in the sequence (result takes precedence in case of a collision?).

personally, i wouldn't support both (complicates things).

to me, a reasonable behavior is that the last write of a parameter value wins

Let me try to describe why I support the current implementation. It has a natural definition as [function composition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_composition):

```
(a1 sequence a2)(args) = a2(a1(args))
```

This plays nicely with the intuition that serverless architecture such as OpenWhisk give you "functions in the cloud".

Now, in the variant where arguments are forwarded to all actions in the sequence, I don't understand if they are also forwarded to the final output? If they are, then:

```
a1 != (a1 sequence identity)
```

...because the second version also returns the input arguments. ~~If they are not forwarded, then sequencing doesn't compose:~~

```
(a1 sequence (a2 sequence a3)) != ((a1 sequence a2) sequence a3)
```

~~In the first case, `a3` has access to the input argument of `a1`, in the second case, it does not.~~

I find both alternatives less intuitive than having to explicitly copy some of the inputs to the output of an action.

I understand of course that there are use cases where forwarding is desirable (maybe passing authentication tokens?), but I would prefer that we explicitly identify them first, and solve them by more appropriate means that changing the definition of action sequencing.

_Edit_ my second example is wrong. I need to think more about the second sub-scenario.

> Now, in the variant where arguments are forwarded to all actions in the sequence, I don't understand if > they are also forwarded to the final output? If they are, then:
>  a1 != (a1 sequence identity)

Suppose they are in fact forwarded to the final output.

You are correct that 
`a1 != (a1 sequence identity)`

Recall that actions produce and consume maps.   Define for map M, M[p] is the value of M for key p, and undefined if  M does not contain the key p

If we define actions A and B are equivalent (===) iff 
`for all x,p: A(x)[p] == B(x)[p]  whenever both A[p] and B[p] are defined.`

I would like to claim that 
`a1 === (a1 sequence identity)`
I think your theorem holds, but I'm not sure I like the assumption that `{ "password": "123456" }` and `{}` are the same object.

Clearly they are not the same object.    But that may be a valid and useful definition of "actions are equivalent" despite this fact.

In fact I think it's quite common in math to define two functions to be equivalent if they are equal wherever they are both defined.   I can probably dig up examples if requested.

One more thing we should clarify in scenario B is whether the default parameters are forwarded as well. If I do:

```
wsk action create foo -p token secr3t foo.js
wsk action create bar --sequence foo baz
```

...does `baz` always receive the `token` parameter when used in the `bar` sequence?

> Clearly they are not the same object. But that may be a valid and useful definition of "actions are equivalent" despite this fact.
> 
> In fact I think it's quite common in math to define two functions to be equivalent if they are equal wherever they are both defined. I can probably dig up examples if requested.

Sure, it can be a definition. It has strange properties, though, like the fact that it doesn't induce an equivalence relation, since `f1 === f2 && f2 === f3` doesn't imply `f1 === f3` (take `f2 := function (args) { return {}; }`, which is equivalent to every other action, for a particularly egregious example).

This discussion on the proper definition of equivalence is a bit of a digression anyway. My concrete concern was "leaking" of input values, but I think the question above about default parameters is a better way to frame the issue.

In any case, my goal is not (I swear!) to write equations. I just really hope that it is clear from the discussion we are having that there are subtle implications behind both options A and B.

What are the subtleties on A? That some users (me included) made the mistake of thinking it was B? Assuming A is the current semantics. I prefer we keep the current semantics which fit more naturally in composition or streaming. 

We don't distinguish default vs other arguments now. I don't think we should either.

> What are the subtleties on A? That somehow some users (me included) made the mistake of thinking it was B?

Yes, and the mistake is reasonable, if you think procedurally:

```
inputs1 = ...
results1 = do_action_1 // inputs1 in scope
results2 = do_action_2 // both inputs1 and results2 in scope
```

I like version A (the current implementation) better. I find it simpler. Also, option B can be simulated by copying inputs to outputs. If we have only option B in place, you can't avoid passing the params to all actions in the sequence, whether they need it or not. 

I don't like the idea of supporting both versions. It complicates design and interfaces unnecessarily.

OK, let's consider a use case.

I want to create a an action 'translatedForecast' which gives me the weather.com forecast in a language 'L' which is a runtime parameter.

I have as building blocks 2 actions: 'forecast' and 'translate' .    The latter takes a string 'S' and a language 'L' and gives me 'S' translated into language 'L'.    

These are library (system) packages - not my own.

Option B lets me write 'translatedWeather := 'forecast' , 'translate'
Option A forces me to write a bunch of nasty glue code.

Agree/disagree?

That glue code was what i was concerned about aswell. Passing the top-level parameters to all functions is a more general strike and let's you include more general functions (like system packages) in your flow without the need of writing glue code. In Steve's example above, it's not even possible to pass the language parameter L at runtime, right? You'ld need to bind it at creation time which would decrease reusability of the sequence itself.

The trade off is simple: globally scoped immutable variables (which means in your example say there was also an API key that is now accessible to third party code that it has no business seeing), or locally scoped ones which may require you to add a level of indirection so that instead of composing the third party action directly in the sequence, there is a wrapper around each that filters and passes whatever parameters that one may need (this is the glue code referred to above).

Global variables are convenient, but leak information.

There may also be unintended consequences. Suppose two actions in the sequence use the same key but the semantics are different or require different values (e.g., API key again). How can you disambiguate? You'll have to write the glue code anyway. This is not an inherent problem to whisk.

@psuter lays these out as either function composition or a procedure implementing a sequence.

We could approach this differently: when creating a sequence, you can optionally provide a function `projectParamrers` which projects from the input arguments that are applied to the sequence those specific to each action in the sequence (by position or name). The projected parameters are merged with the results of a previous action before applying the next action in the sequence. I think this can be reduced to a function composition... Thinking.

**Global variables are convenient, but leak information.**

Absent any new constructs, I think this sentence captures the tradeoff perfectly.

i'm wondering whether the 'information leakage' is a big issue, given it's not sth behind the scenes, but the way how global variables work would be documented transparently -- and everyone can decide whether they want to leverage action sequences or not. i'd err on the side of convenience and if someone wants to have granular control over how variables flow, they can still call actions programmatically

To make things concrete, here's another use case to consider:

I have 2 library methods 'cipher' and 'send-email' : 

cipher takes 2 parameters (privateKey, cleartext) and produces ciphertext.
send-email takes 2 parameters (party, msg) and sends the msg to party via email.

These are both library/system packages.  send-email is provided by SendCompany, whom I do not trust with my cleartext.   I do trust the cipher package.

I want create an action sequence sendEncryptedToJoe.
First I create action myCipher which binds privateKey to myPrivateKey.
Then I create action mySend which binds send-email to party == Joe.

So I create
`sendEncryptedToJoe := myCipher , mySend`

But under semantics B, SendCompany gets my cleartext -- and then sells it to BadGuy.   I didn't understand this because I didn't RTFM or whatever, so I'm unhappy.
in that case -- wouldn't party have to be a global variable?
No party would not have to be global -- note that I bound it in mySend
so i can't pass it in during runtime / action invocation?

> so i can't pass it in during runtime / action invocation?

Not for the purposes of this example.   This example is intended to demonstrate an information leak.
what if i wanted to pass in the email address during action invocation (which is not unrealistic -- usually you want to send emails to more than one fixed person) ?

The point I'm trying to make by these examples is : translateForecast illustrates convenience.   sendEncryptedToJoe illustrates an information leak.    

Yes, semantics A makes it more inconvenient to pass the email address to the 2nd action.

In other words: yes, we can modify sendEncryptedToJoe to create an example which also highlights convenience, and yes we can modify translateForecast to create an example which also highlights information flow.    I chose NOT to do so on purpose, so that we had concrete examples for each issue in isolation.

yeah, i agree -- these are good examples to illustrate the pro's and con's for each scenario.

the point i was trying to make -- in my mind, this is not only a balancing of convenience vs. data protection, but also one of wide vs. narrow applicability.

if we go for the convenience path, the sequencing feature has a much lower barrier to entry / is in many cases easier to adopt. the 'data leakage' oriented approach would in my mind a bit harder to understand and more manual glue code would have to be written, i.e. it wouldn't have as much applicability.

This issue also touches on re-usability of packaged actions.  Actions that don't feed the correct parameters to the downstream sequenced actions can't be used directly.  I encountered this when trying to store a document using cloudant/write, then pass that document to another action so I don't have to do a DB lookup.  The current cloudant/write action only returns the _id and _rev from Cloudant. I'm forced copy the cloudant/write action and customize it.  As @sjfink says, this is messy glue code. We're forcing developers to go through source code instead of just using shared packages off the shelf.

There's definitely a difference in authoring an action using the "standalone" mindset vs "sequence" mindset.  In my cloudant/write example, the current return object makes complete sense if the action is used standalone.  However, if I were to write a new cloudant/write action that I knew would only be used as part of a sequence, I would treat the input parameters much like Servlet Filters do -- I can use and modify the input parameters and then pass the mutated parameters down the line to the next action.  @rabbah 's idea of project parameters is a start -- could I have a mechanism to customize the behavior of an action depending on whether its running standalone or as part of a sequence?
Note: @starpit's changes were merged in commit 0a4eda3.

The current implementation feels more intuitive and simpler IMHO. I can understand the benefits the second approach brings but it feels like there would be more unintended consequences ("I have to remember to return an empty parameter with the same name for each input parameter I don't want to leak to the next actions....").

I'm not sure you'll really ever get away with writing some "glue" code if you are joining third-party actions together, e.g. in the forecast+translate scenario what if the providers use different names for the language parameter? I think I'd just write a meta-action that took the parameters, called the services using whisk.invoke and then return the results.

another consideration we should factor in is...originally, a key motivation for introducing sequences was that the user doesn't have to write code. if lots of glue code or umbrella actions need to be written, that value props lowers.

The glue code is a red herring - if you can curry your arguments by binding them ahead of time to the action create, you can still apply the conservative mode of strict function composition. you will have to write glue code whenever the action you want to use from a third party doesn't do exactly what you want. I think leaking by default may have the exact opposite effect. If we start with the restrictive model - which everyone I know of that initially complained later accepted - we can always relax later. Starting with the permissive mode makes it harder. Perhaps more real evidence needs to be collected on the common case.

>  if you can curry your arguments by binding them ahead of time to the action create, you can still apply the conservative mode of strict function composition

while it is technically possible, binding action parameters (which are dynamically provided during runtime) before action invocation is not really a common pattern today and it also requires additional coding. i'm not against a more restrictive model, but we need to be clear that this limits the addressable set of scenarios / raises the barrier of entry. there is no good or bad -- it's just about trade-offs.

agree -- the coding approach is definitely the most flexible one.

originally, we intended sequences to make it easy (ie with no code) run actions in sequence.

if we err on the safe side for sequences, we don't have an easy solution anymore for sequencing.

if we err on the easy side for sequences, we have an easy solution for simple chaining, and still a more complex one (coding) for more complex sequences.

what's your take on that?

@mbehrendt Very good point that sequences are an ease-of-use feature, so we should chose the "easy" semantics (alternative B). I still worry that we make things so easy that people don't realize they're leaking information.

I know others are against supporting both alternatives, but for the sake of brainstorming, what if we allowed you to explicitly specify the "global" parameters. For example

```
wsk action create foo --sequence action1,action2,action3 --param _globals "arg1"
```

This means that only invocation parameter `arg1` will be passed to all actions in the sequence. An empty `_globals` value is equivalent to the current semantics (alternative A).

Continuing the above example, the following invocation:

```
wsk action invoke foo --param arg1 aaa --param arg2 bbb --param arg3 ccc
```

does the following:

```
output1 = action1(arg1 + arg2 + arg3)
output2 = action2(output1 + arg1)
output3 = action3(output2 + arg1)
return output3
```

@vinodmut interesting thought. the potential challenge i see is that for a user the different semantics of parameters is not intuitive. in your `wsk action invoke` example, for me as a user, it seems like all parameters are equal, so i might be irritating why only my first parameter is only available to all actions, and not to others. 

besides that, what would i do if i wanted to have more than 1 global parameter?

also, it might feel arbitrary that i can only pass 'private' parameters to action1, but not to others.

thoughts?

> for me as a user, it seems like all parameters are equal

I think that's how it should be. The user (i.e., the invoker of the action) shouldn't care about the parameter passing semantics within the sequence, and shouldn't even know what the composed actions are. Only the author of the sequence should care about which parameters are "global".

> what would i do if i wanted to have more than 1 global parameter?

`_globals` can be a list of parameters. For example:

```
wsk action create foo --sequence action1,action2,action3 --param _globals "arg1,arg2"
```

thank you -- that makes sense to me.

what about the point that it might feel arbitrary that i can only pass 'private' parameters to action1, but not to others? eg is that a limitation we should accept, while the main value lies in making the declaration of global variables explicit?

> arbitrary that i can only pass 'private' parameters to action1

I don't immediately see a clean way to support this. Do we have any use cases for this? Maybe at this point we ask the developer to write code. :)

I like the solution @vinodmut started sketching a lot, since it makes it explicit which parameters are forwarded. I also like how it's a natural extension of the existing sequencing construct. We could generalize this, and explicitly _bind_ inputs to actions within the sequence. E.g:

```
wsk action create --sequence a1,a2,a3 -b username a1:username a3:user_name -b token a2:auth_token
```

(This would also address @mbehrendt's point above?)

I think it's also clear to most of us that `--sequence` is just the start and that we all fully expect that we'll develop a richer language of action combinators (e.g. `--parallel`, `--recover`, etc.). It would be good if whatever scheme we design applies generally.

The following host groups are currently in discussion:

```
[edge]
[controllers]
[loadbalancers]
[activators]
[kafka]
[elasticsearch]
[kibana]
[entitlement]
[invokers]
```

**Reasoning:**
- A dedicated `edge` group allows us to potentially cluster NGINX. We did not call it NGINX because we want to make it clear that this is the group of hosts that is connected to the internet.
- We separated `controllers` from edge to be able to scale controller independently from NGINX. Otherwise every node that acted as an edge host would have to run both NGINX and controller.
  Also, with the work being done by @perryibm in issue #141 this allows us to easily move controller onto a different node, should we need more power.
- `loadbalancers`and `activators`should also be able to scale on their own. With discussions trending towards merging those into controller, this might be a non-issue soon.
- `kafka` used to scale kafka. we may need to split that into `zookeeper`and `kafka` depending on the way we want to scale out.
- `elasticsearch` has been separated from `kibana` because it scales differently. we want many nodes to run a ES cluster but only one or two to run the kibana UI. 
- `entitlement` contains hosts for external entitlement services. usually empty on open.
- `invokers` contains the invokers as usual.

**Explanation Roles vs. Groups**

Nodes can play one or more roles in a deployment. For example, a node can act as a consul server, while another acts as a router. 

Groups are just collections of individual machines that can be addressed as one. Groups can also play one or more roles which will then propagate to all nodes in that group.
